title: Susanna Reid left ‘infuriated’ by Mr Broccoli after Good Morning Britain appearance
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Susanna Reid has described how she was left ‘infuriated’ and ‘disappointed’ following Mr Broccoli’s appearance on Good Morning Britain.

The activist, who was arrested at the Animal Rebellion protest on Sunday but released without charge, left hosts Piers Morgan and Susanna dumbfounded by playing up to his broccoli identity and pretending to answer calls from a banana.

Through his silly antics however, Susanna expressed on Thursday’s (17 October) show how she was left irritated after he failed to give a convincing argument for why people should switch to veganism and live on a plant-based diet.

Reflecting back on the interview with co-host Ben Shephard, Susanna said: ‘It was infuriating because I’m half vegan anyway aren’t I? I’m vegetarian so I was all ready to hear the argument.’

Mr Broccoli caused quite a stir on Wednesday’s show (Picture: ITV)

She added: ‘I’m not sure how many people he persuaded to go vegan.

‘A number of people arguing he was actually calling for cannibalism, because if we’re all supposed to eat more broccoli, he’d eat himself wouldn’t he?

‘He took those serious arguments and slightly took them to the absurd.’

Susanna even later claimed Mr Broccoli was actually scared of her following the interview.

Susanna Reid and Ben Shephard reflected on the interview (Picture: ITV)

‘I was very disappointed in Mr Broccoli,’ Susanna added. ‘And when we came off air, the director said he was scared of me.’

Later in the show, Susanna explained her frustrations further, saying: ‘I was cross with him because I thought he missed an open goal when it came to try and persuade people.

‘Some people say if you become vegan, or if you cut down to perhaps one meat free day a week, it would have a massive impact on climate change. I think if you had the platform to be able to argue that case and if you just say, “I’m just a broccoli” and pretend to take a call on a banana, you’ve rather lost your audience.’

During the interview with Mr Broccoli, Piers was similarly irked, telling him: ‘The trouble is Mr Broccoli, had you made a very coherent, powerful, science-based argument, you would have had a real impact.

‘You would have a lot of attention through the way you dressed up for your cause, but to come on here and just be an idiot makes us think you’re just an idiot.’

You can catch Good Morning Britain weekdays on ITV at 6am.
